metadata.title: Metal-Organic Framework/Layered Carbon Nitride Nano–sandwiches for Superior Asymmetric Supercapacitor

sections.text: z Materials Science inc. Nanomaterials & Polymers

sections.heading: Metal-Organic Framework/Layered Carbon Nitride Nano–sandwiches for Superior Asymmetric Supercapacitor
sections.text:
Longtao Ma, Huiqing Fan,* Ke Fu, and Yuwei Zhao[a]
The Fe-doped Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks/layered CN nano-sandwiches (Fe-ZIF/CN) and porous C/layered CN nanosandwiches (porous C/CN) were synthesized from a single Metal-Organic Frameworks/layered CN nano-sandwich precursor. The Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN electrode possessed high specific surface area for 1609 and 2048 m2·g 1 respectively and they showed high capacitance values for 1096 and 587 F·g 1 at the current density of 1 A g 1 under three electrode configuration. The electrochemical performance and stable potential windows of the asymmetric supercapacitors (ASCs) based on FeZIF/CN nano-sandwiches (positive electrode) and porous C/ CN (negative electrode) were further evaluated. The high energy density supercapacitor was successfully realized by the appliances (Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN), much better than those of the SSCs based on porous C/CN or Fe-ZIF/CN electrode materials. The advanced ASCs could work within a wide potential window of 0–1.6 V, which contributed to a high specific energy density of 153 W·h·kg 1. The superior performance was ascribed to the high capacitance and the positive synergistic effects of the two electrodes. These encouraging results revealed a potential in exploiting energy storage appliance with high energy density and power density appliance for practical applications.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
High power and energy consumption has put forward stringent specification for energy conversion and storage.[1–5] Electrochemical supercapacitor is regarded as the most promising energy storage appliance due to the higher energy density of their dielectric capacitors, greater power density and longer cycling lifetimes than conventional rechargeable batteries[6–9] The performance of electrochemical energy storage devices is largely dependent upon the electrode materials.[10] High performance electrode materials should possess large electrolyteaccessible surface area to promote charge accumulation, controllable porosity to improve specific capacitance and the rate of capability, high electronic conductivity to enhance the power density, desirable electroactive sites to provide high thermal stability and chemical stability, which determine the cyclic stability, cost-efficiency and availability of preparation process.[10–14]
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a crystalline porous material with exceptional internal pore volumes allow electrolyte ions to access to the microspores and/or mesoporous by diffusion effect.[15, 16] Electrolytes can easily transport into the solid lattice in MOFs and pass out, which endows MOFs with enormous potentials.[17] MOFs constructed by joining metal
ions and various organic ligands can be synthesized at room temperature and the chemical building blocks participate in electron exchange process.[15, 18] Therefore, MOFs can be directly used as a new type of electrode material for energy storage.[15] However, the poor electrical conductivity, steric hindrance to ion insertion and incompatibility between the electrolyte and these MOFs limit its application for supercapacitors.[18]
Two dimensional (2D) carbon materials could enable ultrafast charge/discharge of electric double-layer capacitors; MOFs nanostructures can provide multiple redox reactions for pseudo-capacitor. In addition, two-dimensional (2D) material integrating superior charge transfer and high specific surface area with porous structure for endows MOFs with enormous potentials is a promising host material to realize construction of supercapacitor with high specific energy density and power density.[19, 20] The construction of intriguing nano-architectures for electrodes materials is considered as a fundamental prerequisite to boost the electrochemical performance. Recent years have witnessed great progress in the design of electrode materials to avoid the “dead surface” and allow for more efficient charge and mass exchange.[21, 22] Layered graphic polymeric carbon nitride (CN) with good conductivity, which has a similar structure to graphene, has been recognized as a novel two-dimension nanostructure material.[23–26] Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks (ZIFs) with reminiscent structures of zeolites have been attracted to act as electrode materials due to their regular morphology and highly external pore porosity.[27, 28] However, most of ZIFs exhibit discrete nanoparticles, which hinders the ions of electrolyte transporting into the pore and passing out.[18] To overcome this problem, we immobilize ZIFs nanoparticles on both sides of layered CN to form a 3D nano-sandwiche architecture of porous ZIFs and layered CNs. Recently, amounts of works has been reported to construct asymmetric [a] L. Ma, Prof. H. Fan, K. Fu, Y. Zhao State Key Laboratory of Solidification Processing, School of Materials Science and Engineering Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi’an 710072, China Tel: + 86-29-88494463 Fax: + 86-29-88492642 E-mail: hqfan@nwpu.edu.cn Supporting information for this article is available on the WWW under http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/slct.201601053
Full PapersDOI: 10.1002/slct.201601053
3730ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
supercapacitor (ASCs), which were based on the development of a positive electrode only (basically, metal oxides).[29, 30] Generally, activated carbon and stacked graphene are used as negative electrode materials. However, it is of great difficulty to make the whole surface area contribute to the capacitance and most activated carbons have a capacitance of 50–200 F g 1 in aqueous electrolytes. The asymmetric performance requires contribution from both the positive electrode and the negative electrode.Hence, the challenge for high-performance ASCs is to exploit both positive and negative materials with controllable porosity and easily tuned structure, which could be synthesized by a relatively simple process. A noticeable frontier in material synthesis is the development of two kinds of materials from a single precursor. This idea of “two-for-one” has been realized in some solid materials. But, the ability to tune their compositions without changing their original shapes has not been achieved yet. Hence, we construct ASCs with high energy density and high power density based on 3D Fe doped ZIF/CN and porous C/CN nano-sandwiches from a single precursor through immobilization of ZIFs on both sides of layered CNs. The ASCs (FeZIF/CN//porous C/CN), which integrates the advantages of positive electrode materials consisting of synergistic action of pseudo-capacitance and double-layer capacitance Fe-ZIF/CN with high surface area and good conductivity and negative materials consisting of double layer capacitance porous C/CN, exhibit a high energy density value of 153 W h Kg 1, much higher than that of SSCs (Fe-ZIF/CN// Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN// porous C/CN)

sections.heading: Material characterization
sections.text:
The ZIFs/layered CN-based nano-sandwiches were firstly synthesized by simply depositing uniform ZIFs nanoparticles on
both sides of layered CN and the formation procedure is illustrated in Figure 1. The homogenous ZIFs clusters were formed by zinc ions combining with 2-methyimidazole. The ZIFs clusters were immobilized on the surface of layered CN by reason of the synergetic interaction between the zinc ions and iron ions from ZIFs and oxygen groups from the surface of layered CN. Further, the ZIFs clusters grew and the ultrathin ZIFs layer coating layered CN nano-sandwiches was obtained after stirring for 3 h at room temperature.
The surface morphology and microstructure of as-synthesized products were characterized by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). SEM image of CN nanosheets (Figure S1a) revealed the 2D graphene-like morphology of the nanosheets with the thickness of less than 10 nm. The ZIF/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches (Figure S1b, Figure 2a) displayed the ultrasmall ZIF-8 nanoparticles aggregated together and almost fully coating on both sides of CN nanosheets. Some ZIF crystals were located on the edge of CN nanosheets and showed well-defined crystal morphology, with larger crystal sizes than those located in the middle of CN sheet. This may be caused by the growth fronts of ZIF clusters located on the edge of both sides of CNs coming together. Interestingly, the Fe-ZIF/CN still kept 2D nanosheet structure and appeared very small number of ZIF particles. This is the first example of CN sheets fully covered by ZIF nanocrystals with ultrasmall diameter (around 10 nm). Such a type of sandwich-like structure could effectively prevent the agglomeration of CN nanosheets during chemical reaction and was in favor of fabricating electrolyte materials for supercapacitor with a high density active siwtes and superior conductivity. After the carbonization of ZIF/CN followed by acid etching with 1 M HCl, the carbon materials still revealed the well-reserved nanosheet morphology (Figure 2b). The powder XRD showed that the diffraction pattern of the synthesized sample was in significantly consistent with simulated pattern
Figure 1. Schematic illustration of the preparation process of ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches and nanoporous C/CN nano-sandwiches from ZIF/CN as the single precursor by optimized thermal treatment procedure.
3731ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
from the ZIF-8(CCDC-4118891) (Figure 2c) and the introduction of iron ion didn’t change the crystal structure. In the case of nano-porous C/CN, the presence of two broad peaks from the (002) and (101) planes (Figure 2d) is assigned to the formation of graphitic carbon (sp2-bonded carbon).[31]
To further certify the formation of two-dimensional layered nan-sandwich structure, the TEM images and AFM images were carried out. The ZIF/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches revealed a 2D layered nanosheets and ZIF nanoparticles with the diameter of about 4 nm coating on the CN nanosheets uniformly (Figure 3a). In addition, no ZIF nanoparticles were observed on the outside of the CN layer, indicating a strong binding of ZIF nanoparticles and CN. The carbonization of ZIF/CN gave porous C/CN nano-sandwiches and the Zn nanoparticles were removed by HCl treatment. The porous C/CN displayed layered structure and no Zn particles exist (Figure 3 b). Thus, we successfully synthesized the porous C/CN nano-sandwiches electrode materials. Figure 3 c showed the typical AM image of Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches.The thickness analysis of the FeZIF/CN by AFM revealed an average thickness of around 9 nm (Figure 3 f), which was consistent with the transparent traits of the obtained sandwiches from the TEM image. These clearly demonstrated the formation of thin two-dimensional layered Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwich.
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to investigate the chemical composition and chemical state of ZIF/CN, Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN nano-sandwiches. Three materials contain carbon, nitride, and oxide elements, while the Fe-ZIF/ CN contains zinc and iron contents (Figure 4 a). In detail, the high resolution C 1 s spectrum for Fe-ZIF/CN (Figure 4 b) and ZIF/CN ( Figure S4b) could be fitted in three major peaks at 284.6, 285.7 and 286.9 eV respectively, corresponding to C C bonds of sp2-carbon, C-OH and N-C=O groups.[32] However, the
contents of N-C=O groups in Fe-ZIF/CN was higher than ZIF/, indicating the Fe element contributing to nitrogen integrating on MOF structure. After carbonization and 1 M HCl treatment of ZIF/CN, two new contribution peaks appeared at 287.8 and 290.9 eV, which were assigned to carbon atom singly bonded with nitride atom and p-p* transition loss peak, respectively. (Figure 4e). The high resolution N 1 s spectra for ZIF/CN were fitted with four peaks at about 398.3, 399.8, 401.2, and 402.6 eV, corresponding to pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen, graphitic nitrogen, and pyridinic N+-O , respectively (Figure S4c). Their relative contents were 28.2 %, 20.5 %, 37.5 %, and 13.8 %, respectively. The relative contents of N atoms for porous C/CN was 34.1 %, 28.2 %, 21.0 %, and 16.7 % for pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen, graphitic nitrogen, and pyridinic N+ -O , respectively (Figure 4 f). ZIF/CN and porous C/CN showed similar N atoms bonding configurations due to their identical compositions. The high resolution N 1 s spectrum of Fe-ZIF/CN in Fig 4c was fitted with two peaks at 398.9 and 400.6 eV corresponding to graphitic nitrogen and pyridinic nitrogen.[33] Their relative contents were 60.2 % and 39.8 %, respectively. The high content of pyridinic N+-O found in ZIF/CN was not detected after introducing small amount of Fe species in the carbon matrix, demonstrating that the Fe species accelerated incorporation of nitrogen atoms into the carbon ring, thus leading to an ultrahigh content of graphitic nitrogen.[34] The binding energy peaks locating at 724.8 eV and 712.7 eV could be seen in the high-resolution spectrum of Fe 2p(Figure 4d), which were attributed to Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 originating from Fe O and Fe N in Fe doped ZIF/CN latticethe. And the content of Fe in Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches was 7.8 %. Both Fe N and Fe O species could enhance kinetic of the electrode
3732ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reaction in alkaline conditions and improve specific capacitance of electrode materials.
The specific surface area was determined by nitrogen sorption technique. As expected, our electrode materials exhibited high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and total pore volume. The ZIF/CN, Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN display typeIV isotherm which possesses mainly mesopores based on the IUPAC classification[35, 36] and their surface area were 1099, 1609 and 2048 m2 g 1 respectively. It indicated that distribution of ZIF particles on the surface of CN nanosheets made contributions to high surface area. The corresponding pore size distributions of the three samples calculated by density functional theory were displayed in Figure 5b, indicating that all products possess the mesopores of 10–50 nm.[37] Apparently, the introduction of iron ion increased the pore size, which was
in favor of the electrolyte ion transferring into and passing out electrode materials, leading to high performance supercapacitor.[38]

sections.heading: Electrochemical Characterization
sections.text:
The electrochemical performance of as-synthesized materials was investigated with cyclic voltammetry (CVs) tests and galvanostatic charging-discharging (GCD) using three electrode configurations in electrolyte of 6 M KOH aqueous solution. Figure 6 a displayed the CVs of the CN, ZIF, ZIF/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN at scan rate of 10mV s 1 and potential window 0–0.45 V vs Ag/ AgCl. The ZIF, ZIF/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN electrode exhibited broad redox peaks owing to a typical pseudo-capacitive behavior. Evidently, the currents generated by the pristine CN were negli-
Figure 4. figr4> XPS spectra of (a) survey of Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN, high-resolution (b) C 1 s, (c)N 1 s and (d) Fe 2p spectra for Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches, the highresolution spectra of (e) C1 s and (f) N1 s for porous C/CN.
Figure 5. (a) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of ZIF/CN, Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN at 77 K and (b) the pore size distribution.
3733ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
gible compared with ZIF/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN, which was attributed to the capacitances made by the CN is neglected in the specific capacitance data reported here. The larger voltammetric current for ZIF/CN mainly came from the pseudo-capacitance ZIF. The CVs of the Fe-ZIF/CN, ZIF/CN and ZIF resemble each other as expected. The currents of Fe-ZIF/CN and ZIF/CN sandwiches at the same potential is larger than that of ZIF particles, which indicated that the incorporation of ZIFs into CN made charge transport easier. The results could be attributed to the highly conductive CN nanosheet facilitating the charge transfer and conduction from the electrochemical reactions.
As for the GCD performance at 1 A g 1 current density and their specific capacitance (Figure 6c, 6d), a major charge-discharge platform appeared in Fe-ZIF/CN electrode indicating a major redox reaction occurred in the charge-discharge process, which was consistent with lager current density of Fe-ZIF/CN at same applied potential in CVs. Furthermore, the nonlinear of time dependence on the potential demonstrated the typical pseudo-capacitance behavior from the charge separation at the electrode-electrolyte interface.[39] At low current density, fully accumulated charges in the inner active sites of the electrode materials led to high specific capacitance values. The specific capacitance of Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches was 1096 F g 1 at current density of 1 A g 1, much higher than that of 402.5 F g 1 of ZIF/CN and 150 F g 1 of ZIF particles. The higher specific capacitance was attributed to two factors. One is the uniform deposition of ZIF nanoparticles on the both sides of the high conductive CN nanosheet providing a superior diffusion path for ions and electrons, and a low contact resistance. On the other hand, the introduction of Fe species enhanced the redox reaction. The electrochemical impedance spectrum further re-
vealed the electrochemical performance of as-synthesized electrode materials (Figure 6d). The equivalent series resistance (ESR) including the resistance of KOH aqueous solution, the intrinsic resistance of the electroactive material and the contact resistance at the interface between the electrode and current collector could be obtained from the x-intercept of Nyquist plots. The ESR of the ZIF/CN (0.55 ohm) and Fe-ZIF/CN (0.55 ohm) electrode were much smaller than that of ZIF electrode (1.08 ohm). Hence, the formation of nano-sandwiches substantially increase conductivity of electrode materials remarkably.
An asymmetric capacitor (ASCs) could be constructed using the high capacitance of the redox character of Fe-ZIF/CN nanosandwiches and the fast ion-transport property of porous C/CN as the positive and negative electrodes, respectively. The representative CVs of the Fe-ZIF/CN electrode at various scan rates ranging from 5 to 50 mV s 1 in a potential window of 0–0.45 V were presented in Figure 7a. The CVs exhibited a pairs of redox peaks, particularly at low scan rates, demonstrating the presence of redox reactions of Fe-ZIF/CN during the electrochemical process. The CVs ranging from 5 to 50 mV s 1 with a 10 times increase in the scan rate, but there were no no evident change in the position and shape of the current peaks, indicating the Fe-ZIF/CN electrode in favor of fast redox reactions. These obvious peaks might be assigned to the reversible Faradaic redox processes. Consistent with the CV results, the poorly defined voltage plateaus in the charge/discharge curves suggested the pseudo-capacitive behavior and the presence of some Faradaic process (Figure 7b). The CVs of the porous C/CN electrode showed a typical semi-rectangular shape with a wide potential window of 1.15 V and exhibited near mir-
Figure 6. Comparing electrochemical characterizations of CN, ZIF, ZIF/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches electrodes. (a) CV curves at 10 mV s 1 in 6 M KOH aqueous solution. (b) Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves at a current density of 1 A g 1. (c) Specific capacitance at different current density from 1 to20 A g 1. (d) AC impedance spectrum.
3734ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
ror image current response on voltage reversal, revealing a typical characteristic of an electric double-layer capacitor (Figure 7c). The specific capacitance of the Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN electrode as a function of current densitywas calculated from the charge-discharge curves (Figure 7d). For Fe-ZIF/CN electrode, a maximum specific capacitance reached up to 1,096 Fg 1 at a discharge current density of 1Ag 1, and the corresponding volumetric capacitance was estimated to be 548 F cm 3. With the increase of current density, the specific capacitance of the Fe-ZIF/CN electrode gradually decreased and still kept a high value of 689 F g 1 at 20 A g 1. About 62.9 % of the capacitance for Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches was retained when the current density increases from 1 to 20 A g 1. The much higher specific capacitance of Fe-ZIF/CN electrode than that of the porous C/CN electrode was attributed to the overall capacitance of the Fe-ZIF/CN composite deriving from the combined contribution of the primary redox pseudo-capacitance of ZIF and the electrical double layer capacitance of CN in the composite, whereas the electrical double layer only contributed to the capacitance of porous C/CN electrode. The cycling performance of the Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches and Porous C/CN electrode was determined by repeated charge/discharge test at a current density of 1 A g 1 (Figure 7e). As for Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches electrode, the specific capacitance is 1096 F g 1 for the first cycle and the value decreases to 989 F g 1 with about 9.3 % loss after continuous cycling for 2,000 cycles and the porous C/CN are stable in the process of constant current chargedischarge. Thus, the Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches positive electrode and porous C/CN negative electrode could be applied to electrode materials for high performance supercapacitor in practices. The comparison of CV curves at the scan rate of 10 mV s 1 for Fe-ZIF/CN with porous C/CN nano-sandwiches electrode was displayed in Figure 7 f. The CVs investigation for the porous C/CN electrodes was carried out in the potential window of 1.15-0 V (vs Ag/AgCl), while the CVs for the Fe-ZIF/CN electrode was measured in the potential window of 0–0.45 V (vs Ag/AgCl). Both CVs practically exhibited near mirror-image current response on voltage reversal. However, the CV curve of the Fe-ZIF/CN electrode was more complicated and very distinguished from that of the porous C/CN. A pair of redox peaks could be clearly observed with the cathodic peaks at 0.10 V and anodic peaks around 0.36 V. The remarkable difference could be explained by the fact that the overall capacitance of the porous C/CN nano-sandwiches derives from singly the contribution of the primary electrical double layer capacitance, whereas the electrical double layer and pseudo-capacitance jointly contributes to the capacitance of the Fe-ZIF/CN nanosandwiches. Furthermore, it could be observed (Figure 7e) that these two materials were quite stable in a different range of potentials. Thus, if the total cell voltage could be expressed as the total of the potential range for Fe- ZIF/CN and for porous C/CN nano-sandwiches, the cell potential could be extended up to 1.6 V in 6 M KOH aqueous solution for an asymmetric supercapacitor. As for asymmetric supercapacitor, the charge balance would follow the relationship q+ = q . The charge stored by each electrode depends on the specific capacitance (C), the po-
Figure 7. (a) CV curves Fe-ZIF/CN electrode at different scan rate from 5 to 50 mV s 1 applied voltage 0–0.45 V. (b) Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of FeZIF/CN electrode at different current density from 0.5 to 20 A g 1. (c) CV curves porous C/CN electrode at different scan rate from 5 to 50 mV s 1 applied voltage 1.15-0 V. (d) Specific capacitance of Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN electrodes at different current density from 0.5 to 20 A g 1. (e) Cycling performance of Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN electrodes at a current density of 1 A g 1. (f) Comparative CV curves of porous C/CN and Fe-ZIF/CN electrodes performed in a three-electrode cell in 6 M KOH aqueous solution at a scan rate of 10 mV s 1.
3735ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
tential range for the charge-discharge process (E) and the mass of the electrode (m) following the Equation:[40]
q ¼ C DE m ð1Þ
and for the sake of q + = q , the mass balancing of Fe-ZIF/ CN (m+) and porous C/CN (m-) as positive and negative electrode materials would follow the Equation:
mþ m ¼ C Cþ DE DEþ ð2Þ
On the basis of the specific capacitance values and potential windows found for the Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches and Porous C/CN, the optimal mass ratio between the electrode materials should be
mðFe-ZIF=CNÞ=mðporous C=CNÞ ¼ 0:21
in the asymmetric supercapacitor cell. Electrochemical evaluation of asymmetric capacitor based on porous C/CN nano-sandwiches for negative electrode and Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches for positive electrode. To further evaluate ZIFs/ layered CN derived nano-sandwiches electrode materials for practical application, an asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC) device was assembled by using the Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches as positive electrode and porous C/CN nanosandwiches as negative electrode in 6 M KOH aqueous electrolyte with one piece of cellulose paper as the separator and was
depicted in Figure 8a. Figure 8b displayed the typical CVs of the Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN ASC appliance at various scanning rate between 0 and 1.6 V. Evidently, the CVs showed capacitance from both electric double-layer capacitance and pseudocapacitance. The current density enhanced with the increasing scan rate and all curves exhibited a similar shape. There was no obvious distortion in the CVs even at a high scan rate of 100 mV s 1, indicating excellent fast-charge/discharge properties of the device. The specific capacitance of the ASC calculated from CVs (Figure 8c) was 275.6 F g 1 at the scanning rate of 5mV s 1, and it still retained 124.1 F g 1 at a high scanning rate of 100 mV s 1. The performance was much better than that of reported work (Table.S1), so this nano-sandwich structure materials is suitable for electrode materials.
The galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were carried out at various current densities (Figure 8d). The specific capacitance value at a current density of 1 A g 1 was 432.4 F g 1, which decreased to 202.7 F g 1 even at the high current density of 50 A g 1. The initial voltage loss observed from the discharge curves was small even at high current density, owing to the fast I–V response and low internal resistance of the supercapacitor. The specific capacitance values ranged from 432.4 to 202.7 F g 1 with the current densities increasing from 1 to 50 A g 1 (Figure 8e). About 46.9 % capacitance was retained during this course and the charge/discharge curves remain in a good symmetry, indicating the excellent electrochemical reversibility and capacitive characteristics of the ASC supercapacitor.
Furthermore, a Ragone plot (specific power vs specific energy) in Figure 8 f, as a performance indicator for energy stor-
Figure 8. Electrochemical evaluation of ASCs (Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN). (a) Schematic illustration of the ASC device using Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwiches and porous C/CN nano-sandwiches as the positive and negative electrodes, respectively. (b) CV curves of the ASC device at various scan rates from 5 to 100 mV s 1 measured between 0 and 1.6 V. (c) Plot of the specific capacitance as a function of scan rate. (d) Galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of ASC cell at various current densitiesfrom 1 to 20 A g 1. (e) Dependence of specific capacitance on the applied current density. (f) Ragone plots of SSCs and ASC based on Fe-ZIF/ CN nano-sandwiches and porous C/CN nano-sandwiches electrodes.
3736ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
age devices, was used to evaluate the performance of our ASCs. We fabricated two types of SSCs appliance (Fe-ZIF/CN// Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN//porous C/CN) and one ASCs appliance (Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN) for comparison. It could be seen that the porous C/CN//porous C/CN capacitor exhibited maximal specific energy of 41 W h kg 1 at specific power of 800 W kg 1, and Fe-ZIF/CN//Fe-ZIF/CN capacitor exhibited maximal specific energy of 11 W h kg 1 at specific power of 400 W kg 1. For Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN ASC capacitor, it exhibited maximal specific energy of 153 W h kg 1 at specific power of 800 W kg 1. Even at high power density of 40000 W kg 1, the ASC still delivered an energy density of 72 W h kg 1.
The results rewealed that the presence of a high inner porosity, superior ion and electron conduction, and both pseudocapacitive and double electrode layer capacitive material FeZIF/CN contributed to higher current sweeps, whereas the porous C/CN was mainly responsible for providing a stable and wide potential window. The synergistic effect made major contributions to the high performance of the ASCs. Life-cycle measurements were carried out using CVs at scan rate of 10 mV s 1 and charge-discharge studies at current density of 1 A g 1 up to 2000 cycles (Figure S6a, b). Our ASCs exhibited a very promising performance up to 2000 cycles, with no evidence decrease in capacitance. Hence, we had exploited a novel and efficient way to improve the ASCs of high specific energy density, specific power density, and rate capability using 3D MOFs/ layer carbon nitride-derived nano-sandwiches materials.

sections.heading: Mechanism
sections.text:
The excellent performances of asymmetric supercapacitor (FeZIF/CN//C/CN) were determined by the unique nano-sandwiches structure and high internal pore porosity of electronic materials. The metal organic framework (MOF) materials possessed high pore density and large quantities of pores existed
in the internal volume. Furthermore, the MOF were immobilized in 2D layered CN nanosheets to form pathways for ions and electrons migration. The channel resistance of CN nanosheet was really low (only 0.19 ohm), which was in favor of ion and electrons diffusion. The decay of capacitance at the highfrequency domain could be assigned to distributed charge storage in electrode material pores and ion diffusion control.[41] The suppressed ions diffusion led to the steep decay of capacitance at high-frequency and small capacitance at 1000 Hz. A perfect electron freeway was supplied by the 2D CN nanosheets and super capacitance of charge was provided by ZIF nanoparticles, so the nano-sandwiches electrode show superior performance. The inner contact resistance of ZIF/CN sandwiches electrode was far smaller than ZIF particles electrode owing to amounts of inter-particle contacts (Figure 5d). A large resistance led to a larger initial voltage drop and smaller available output power and energy and it also contributed to the earlier appearance of ‘knee’ inflexion at a lower frequency for ZIF electrodes. The capacitance approached to its intrinsic value at the “keen” point through utilizing the sandwiches and a high porosity structure[42] In addition, the agglomeration of ZIF nanoparticles resulted in inaccessible surfaces and the capacitance loss. The ZIF nanoparticles were attached and rigidly fixed on both sides of CN nanosheets without agglomeration of nanoparticles and inter-particle contacts, which contributed to the excellent capacitance. Undoubtedly, the power density and energy density of ZIF/CN sandwiches were thus outstanding.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
A high-performance asymmetric supercapacitor based on FeZIF/CN nano-sandwiches and porous C/CN nano-sandwiches as positive and negative electrode materials was successfully constructed from a single precursor ZIF/ layered CN. The 3D po-
Figure 9. Schematic models dispalying easy ion diffusion and minimized inner contacts for a nano-sandwiches electrode and corresponding (b) equivalent circuits. (c) Equivalent capacitances calculated from the frequency response analysis.
3737ChemistrySelect 2016, 1, 3730 – 3738 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
rous nano-sandwiches structure with amounts of inner poles afforded a favorably accessible path way for electrolyte ions and electrons. The introduction of iron ions remarkably enhanced the capacitance of positive electrode materials (1096 F g 1 in three electrode configuration). The ASCs (Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN) exhibited high specific energy density of 153 W h kg 1, high specific power density of 40000 W kg 1 and good cycling stability at an operating voltage of about 1.6 V in 6 M KOH aqueous electrolytes. This encouraging strategy was easy to be tunable and expected to be a promising candidate for application in high-performance energy storage systems.
Supporting Information
Experimental methods. Detailed discussions and characterizations of Fe-ZIF/CN nano-sandwich and nanoporous carbon/ CN nano-sandwich.

metadata.abstractText: The Fe-doped Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks/layered CN nano-sandwiches (Fe-ZIF/CN) and porous C/layered CN nanosandwiches (porous C/CN) were synthesized from a single Metal-Organic Frameworks/layered CN nano-sandwich precursor. The Fe-ZIF/CN and porous C/CN electrode possessed high specific surface area for 1609 and 2048 m·g 1 respectively and they showed high capacitance values for 1096 and 587 F·g 1 at the current density of 1 A g 1 under three electrode configuration. The electrochemical performance and stable potential windows of the asymmetric supercapacitors (ASCs) based on FeZIF/CN nano-sandwiches (positive electrode) and porous C/ CN (negative electrode) were further evaluated. The high energy density supercapacitor was successfully realized by the appliances (Fe-ZIF/CN//porous C/CN), much better than those of the SSCs based on porous C/CN or Fe-ZIF/CN electrode materials. The advanced ASCs could work within a wide potential window of 0–1.6 V, which contributed to a high specific energy density of 153 W·h·kg . The superior performance was ascribed to the high capacitance and the positive synergistic effects of the two electrodes. These encouraging results revealed a potential in exploiting energy storage appliance with high energy density and power density appliance for practical applications.
